div.l: The more wille I stele whan I take
In stede of floure ȝit will I ȝif hem brenne
The grettest clerkes ben noȝt the wysest mēnne
As whilom to the wolf thus spake the mare
Of all her arte counte I noȝt a tare
Out of the dore he goth full priuely
Whan that he saugh hys tyme softly
He loketh vp ⁊and doune til he hath yfounde
The clerkes hors ther͗e as he stode ybounde
Behynd the mylle vnder a leuesele
And to this horse he goth hym fair ⁊and wele
He stripeth of the brydell right anone
And whan the hors was lavse he gynneth to gon̄
Toward the fenne there wilde mares renne
And forth with we he þurgh thik and thurgh thenne
This myller goth agayn no worde he seide
But doth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
Till that hir corne was fair ⁊and wele ygrounde
And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
This Iohn goth oute ⁊and fynde his hors awey
And gan to crie harow and wele away
Oure hors is lost Alen for goddes banes
Steppe on thi fete come of man̄ al at anes
Alas oure warden̄ hath his palfrey lorne
This alen̄ all forgate both mele ⁊and corne
Alle was out of his mynde his housbondrie
What whilke way is he gane he gan to crie
The wyf come lepyng Inward at a renne
She seid alas ȝoure hors goth in the fenne
With wilde mares as fast as he may go
Vnthank come vn his hede that bounde hym soo
And he that shuld better haue knytte the reyne
Alas qᵈuod Iohn alen̄ for cristes peyne
